column6: Job/Team Function

DE&S Director Human Resources works in partnership with DE&S Directors to identify ways in which people can contribute more effectively to delivering the outputs and key targets of the organisation, and to shape the way in which people are led, managed and developed on a daily basis.

Corporate Approvals Performance and Risk (CAPR) supports DE&S corporate leadership in the drive to improve DE&S performance though the provision of key business services including performance and risk management, approvals support and the framework within which through life investment assurance operates.
The FAST team delivers equipment, training and logistics services for the Typhoon and Tornado aircraft as well as the Battle of Britain Memorial Flight and Aircrew Escape and Survival equipments.

DE&S Intelligence, Surveillance, Target Acquisition and Reconnaissance (ISTAR) Comrcl-Hd is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to D ISTAR and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.

Director Ships is responsible for the procurement, through life support and eventual disposal of ships and equipment for the Royal Navy and other services involved in maritime operations.  This ranges from major projects like the future aircraft carrier through to outboard motors used on rigid raiding craft and all of the spares with the engineering and logistical expertise that goes with this.

DES Air Support Comrcl-Hd is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to Director Air Support and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.

Responsible for delivering design support, logistic support and regulating approval for in-service submarine nuclear propulsion plants.  Also responsible for developing the technology for the Next Generation Nuclear Propulsion Plant for use in the Successor submarine.

International Relations Group is the focal point within DE&S for initiatives and policies in multi-national organisations such as NATO, the European Commission, the European Defence Agency (EDA) and the Organisation for Joint Armaments Co-operation (OCCAR), is responsible for effective government-to-government relationships with key national partners such as the USA and France.  IRG also leads on the negotiation of procurement-related Memoranda of Understanding (MOU) with partner nations.
column19: DECS staff - reported on HOCS return

column6: The Cost Assurance and Analysis Service (CAAS) is the MOD centre of excellence for pricing and costing support to the acquisition community, enabling continuous improvement of the acquisition process, risk reduction, and ensuring best value for money for Defence.

Responsible for delivering military flying training through a programme of incremental acquisition that demonstrates commercial best practice; ensuring the transition from legacy equipment and platforms is seamless.

The Intelligence, Surveillance, Target Acquisition and Reconnaissance (ISTAR) Programme Delivery Group 1 is responsible for electronic and imagery-based intelligence systems and technologies, providing services to the MOD and to other government departments.
DES Ships Comrcl Hd is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to D Ships and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.
The Information Systems & Services (ISS) Networks team is responsible for all information and communications networks in the MOD.
The Naval Authority Group provides whole ship and submarine safety and technical services to the maritime community within the MOD.

Weapons Engineering is responsible for the Defence Ordnance Safety Group (DOSG) and the Trials, Evaluation Services and Targets Project Team.  DOSG is the MOD’s focal point for Ordnance, Munitions and Explosives Safety.  DOSG provides policy, advice and regulatory functions on behalf of the Secretary of State and monitors departmental performance to provide assurance to the Secretary of State through the Defence Ordnance Safety Board.
Responsible for the acquisition and support of all current and future helicopter platforms and equipment in the MOD.

Responsible for delivering the new Astute Class capability safely and affordably to Navy Command, including provision of the Astute Class Training Service and the Initial Astute Class Support Solution.

Responsible for provision of the nuclear warhead and Strategic Weapons System (SWS) by managing acquisition of hardware, logistic support and gaining regulatory approval for the nuclear warhead and SWS for in-service Vanguard Class and the Successor SSBN.

The Chief of Materiel Joint Enablers ensures projects in his domain (Helicopters, Intelligence, Surveillance, Target Acquisition and Reconnaissance, and Information Systems and Services) are delivered to agreed time, cost and performance targets and that DE&S’s support to current and future operations is delivered coherently and effectively.
The Director Safety and Engineering is responsible for driving, developing and delivering safety and engineering expertise and capabilities in order to equip and support our armed forces.

Director Finance has four principle functions: to provide sound financial accounting for DE&S; to provide financial management information to the Board and operating centres; to ensure regularity and propriety throughout DE&S and support the financial assurance process in Operating Centres; to improve financial professionalism across DE&S.

The Intelligence, Surveillance, Target Acquisition and Reconnaissance (ISTAR) Operating Centre exists to deliver and support capabilities that provide information superiority and protection, critical to successful operations of the Royal Navy, Army and Royal Air Force.

The Bowman and Tactical Communication and Information Systems (BATCIS) Delivery Team is responsible for delivery and through life support of the Bowman secure voice and data tactical network to all three Front Line Commands, approximately 45,000 radios and the associated complex installation of this equipment into over 13,000 platforms, a number of bespoke Tactical CIS equipments, 60,000 standard Personal Role Radios (PRR) and 11,000 secure versions of the PRR.

Responsible for delivery of complex warship design and build programmes. Queen Elizabeth Class Aircraft Carriers and Type 26 programmes. Responsible for the future support strategy of new platforms. Implementation of the BAE Systems Terms of Business Agreement.

The Information Systems and Services (ISS) Programmes Group is responsible for managing a coherent programme across ISS which develops and delivers a dynamic set of integrated information and communication services, optimises the use of resources and delivers maximum benefit for the end user and the MOD.

The Unmanned Air Systems (UAS) team manages all DE&S UAS programmes/projects to deliver current and future frontline capability; informing the UK’s UAS-related acquisition strategies, policy and standards. The team takes a leading role in the development of formative UAS safety and engineering standards, as well as shaping future UAS research and development and unmanned combat air capability.

Responsible for delivering the F35 Lightning II Joint Strike Fighter into UK service. Additionally responsible for preparing the UK Infrastructure to receive, operate and support Lightning through life.

In-service support and new acquisition programmes for the Royal Fleet Auxiliary (RFA), Ice Patrol, Fishery Protection, Hydrographic, training ships and the small boats flotilla. Also responsible for the Future Landing Craft programme.
The Submarine Operating Centre is responsible for the procurement, through-life support and eventual disposal of all submarine assets, and for the maintenance of Deterrent systems.

DES Submarines Commercial Head is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to D Submarines and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.

Responsible for support to all in-service submarines (Swiftsure, Trafalgar and Vanguard Classes), decommissioning and dismantling, supporting the introduction of new submarines into service, and submarine escape and rescue.

Maritime Platform Systems is responsible for managing over 200 master equipments, 650 suppliers and 300,000 stock numbers in support of surface ships and submarines for the Royal Navy, Royal Fleet Auxiliary and other areas of the MOD.

Responsible for managing support to in-service Royal Navy surface ships in scope of the Surface Ship Support Programme, including T23 Frigates, T42 and T45 Destroyers, Landing Platform Dock/Landing Platform Helicopter, Aircraft Carrier (Carrier Vertical Strike), Mine Counter Measures Vessels and Landing Craft, as well as Minehunter Patrol Control Capability and historic platforms such as HMS VICTORY.
Head of Defence Equipment & Support
Responsible for resource management including finance, planning, corporate approvals, performance and risk
Responsible for Parliamentary business and corporate communications

The DE&S Infrastructure team is responsible for the most complex and difficult infrastructure in the MOD estate, ranging from the three major Naval bases to very large explosive stores.  The DE&S Infrastructure itself poses significant operational, safety, security and environmental risks to maintaining outputs and the groups within the Infrastructure team provide expert knowledge and skills to manage those risks.

The Maritime Change Programme provides an overarching framework encompassing a federation of change programmes in the DE&S Maritime domain. The vision is to achieve an optimised maritime sector, including the three Naval Bases.

Head of Commercial Joint Support Chain is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to D JSC and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.

Finance Head for the Maritime Change Programme. This programme provides an overarching framework encompassing a federation of change programmes in the DE&S Maritime domain. The vision is to achieve an optimised maritime sector, including the three Naval Bases.

The Joint Support Chain sustains the UK's fighting power through the delivery of materiel and the movement of personnel world-wide. It also provides storage and distribution of materiel; management of allocated commodities, services and items; authorised policy and approved technical support services. It facilitates strategic deployment; sustainment and recovery of forces.

Supply Chain Management provides a range of supply and support chain change programmes and capabilities to DE&S and to the Front Line to help improve effectiveness and efficiency, to maintain the coherence of the Joint Supply Chain, and to promote and develop the Joint Supply Chain as a single end-to-end process.

Head of Commercial, Commands and Centre is responsible for the provision of commercial advice and services to the Front Line Commands and to the MOD Centre, inclulding the management of centrally-administered enabling contracts.

Defence Supply Chain Operations and Movements (DSCOM) delivers Supply Chain and Movements Support to operational and training theatres around the globe.  DSCOM provides the operations focus for DE&S, coordinating wider DE&S operational support activity to ensure the timely and correctly prioritised delivery of equipment and materiel.
The Logistics Commodities Cluster teams comprise Defence Food Services, Defence Clothing, and Medical & General Supplies.

Head of Commercial Land Equipment (LE) is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to D LE and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.

The Operational Support Programmes Group delivers a broad portfolio of in-service outputs, Urgent Operational Requirements and new equipment projects in the Land Environment, including vehicles and battlefield utilities and services.
Land Equipment is responsible for all tracked and wheeled vehicles, battlefield infrastructure, simulated training in the land environment and dismounted soldier equipment, including weapons.

Combat Mobility Programme provides development, procurement, support and sustainment of protected patrol vehicles and mobility support equipment, vehicles and systems for the armed forces.  Vehicles include Mastiff, Ridgeback, Jackal, Wolfhound, Husky, Coyote, Snatch, Vector and Warthog; military bridging; the Terrier combat engineer system and the new Light Protected Patrol Vehicle (LPPV), together with large elements of the Counter-IED capability.
Weapons Support is responsible for storage, processing, and out-loading of both general munitions and complex weapons from eight sites across UK and in Germany.

The Customer Support Team (Land) supports COM(Land) in his responsibilities as a DE&S Board Member, as DE&S Land Forces Champion, Army Board member and Army lead for the Logistic Defence Line of Development. In this capacity, CST (L) also acts as a key agent in developing, maintaining and supporting DE&S’ relationship with Land Forces.

Information Systems & Services is responsible for the delivery and support of information systems and services to operations and to all parts of the UK defence community, including other areas of government.

The Service Operations Directorate is accountable for assuring the delivery of all Information Systems and Services outputs, providing secure Information and Communication Services to the operational commander in the field.

The Defence Information Infrastructure (DII) Delivery Group is responsible for the provision of secure computing infrastructure at fixed sites in UK and overseas, on board ships and submarines, and at deployed HQ in operational theatres.

The MOD Network Technical Authority (NTA) is responsible for ensuring the technical coherence of Networks and for informing its future architecture and design.  The NTA is responsible for formalising the technical approach for any component or system that will be connected to the Defence Network; this is to minimise impact to the network and ensure changes conform to the long-term strategy and architecture for the Defence Network.
The Crypto & Cyber team is responsible for delivering efficient and effective application services across Defence.

Information Systems and Services (ISS) Hd Commercial is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to D ISS and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.

The DES Airworthiness Team is responsible for establishing and leading the delivery of a safety management, engineering and technical assurance strategy for the DE&S Air domain, and specifically the Air Support teams.

Responsible for the delivery of Airseeker aircraft and in-service support, and the in-service support of Sentinel battlefield surveillance aircraft plus ground stations and Sentry airborne early warning aircraft.
The Helicopters delivery team 1 area is responsible for acquisition, upgrading and support of the Merlin, Lynx and Sea King Helicopters.

The Combat Air Operating Centre is responsible for acquisition and support for all current and future fast jet platforms. The in-service support activities cover Tornado, Typhoon, Training Aircraft, and Aircrew Escape and Survival equipment for all fixed and rotary wing aircraft in RAF service. Lightning II (otherwise known as Joint Strike Fighter) is the team's major future programme, alongside Unmanned Air Systems acquisition and support for Reaper, Hermes 450 and Watchkeeper.

Portsmouth Naval Base is the home of almost two-thirds of the Royal Navy's surface ships, including the current carriers, Type 45, Type 42, Hunt-class mine hunters, and half of the Type 23 fleet; and will be the home of the Queen Elizabeth Class.  Commander Naval Base Portsmouth is responsible for the delivery of the Sea Mounting Centre at Marchwood, and is the Senior Reporting Officer for the Defence Marine Services. The Naval Base Commander is accountable to Director Ships for the delivery and support of the Surface Ships based at Portsmouth.  In partnership with the BAES Surface Ships, he is responsible for providing the quality of service outputs required to support ships, support the base and support people at the Naval Base.

Clyde Naval Base comprises the Faslane Naval Base, the Royal Navy Armament Depot Coulport, HMS Caledonia at Rosyth, the Navy Buildings at Greenock and a number of military ranges.  As the Authorisee for the Nuclear site, the Naval Base Commander is accountable to Director Submarines for the delivery, support and safety of the nuclear programme.  In partnership with the MOD, Babcock Marine is responsible for providing the quality of service and support of three Naval Base outputs of Vessels, Weapons and Operational support.  The Babcock Terms of Business Agreement sets out a long term partnering relationship for surface ship and submarine support at Rosyth and Clyde.

Devonport Naval Base is home to the Royal Navy’s large amphibious ships, the Hydrographic Surveying Squadron, Trafalgar Class submarines and approximately two thirds of the frigate force. It is also the principal base for Flag Officer Sea Training and his operational sea training staff.  The Naval Base Commander is accountable to Director Ships and Director Submarines for the upkeep of all ships and submarines based at Devonport.  Babcock Marine own approximately one half of the site, and the Babcock Terms of Business Agreement sets out a long term partnering agreement for surface ship and submarine support at Devonport.
The ISTAR programme delivery group 2 is responsible for Special Projects, Force Protection and CBRN (Chemical, Biological, Radiological and Nuclear) protection capabilities.

Responsible for the delivery and in-service support of the Armed Forces'  transport aircraft (A400M, C17 and Hercules), in-service support of the RAF comms fleet (BAe125 and BAe146) and the VC10 tanker aircraft.  Also responsible for the delivery of Voyager (the RAF's new strategic transport/tanker aircraft), the TriStar transport/tanker, as well as the procurement and support of airborne delivery equipment.

The team is responsible for the acquisition and support of general munitions (shells, bullets, grenades etc), torpedoes, cruise missiles, naval guns of all calibres, air guns and missiles for helicopters and fixed wing aircraft, shoulder launched missiles and freefall bombs. Many are procured internationally and the portfolio excludes weapons covered by the Team Complex Weapons initiative.

Responsible for overall portfolio management of the Land Equipment Operating Centre including the effective prioritisation of resources to match customer requirements, generic safety, engineering and programme management issues and delivery of a Programme Support Function to Land Programme Boards.
The Helicopters delivery team 2 is responsible for the acquisition, upgrading and support of the Chinook, Puma and Gazelle helicopters.

Responsible for helping to ensure the quality and veracity of financial information that is to be used for management reporting and decision-making across DE&S and the Department, and for the production of auditable financial accounts.

Resources & Plans manages the DE&S strategic planning and programming process, and provide programming advice and support to key stakeholders within DE&S and MOD. They maintain programme coherence as well as maximising outputs within the funding available.

Responsible for drawing together the UK's nuclear submarine projects into a single, cohesive programme that is underpinned by common processes, is marked by a consistent approach to industry and informs balance of investment decisions.
The primary role of Customer Support Team (Air) is to provide situational awareness and business intelligence to enable Chief of Materiel (Air) to assure DE&S performance across the Air Domain.
The Head of Industrial Policy (Secretariat) is responsible for research and production of the White Paper on Defence Equipment and Support and acts as the PQs/FOI focal point on these issues.
column19: DECS staff - reported on HOCS return

column6: Responsible for Commercial Assurance
column19: DECS staff - reported on HOCS return

column6: Responsible for assisting DE&S Operating Centres to improve their teams’ programme, project and technology management, as well as providing DE&S programme management assistance.
DECS is responsible for external industry facing commercial activities which require a deep, long term understanding of the industrial base.
column19: DG Exports reported in HOCS chart

column6: The Weapons Programmes Team drives the strategy for the Weapons Operating Centre. It leads on all cross cutting issues including operational support; future business; technology strategy and delivery; Team Complex Weapons strategic planning and approvals; planning and programming; business management; change and business Improvement, HR planning and management; and Weapon/Platform integration.

Logistic Services has three principal business areas: Logistic Services, which provides a materiel storage, processing and distribution service within the supply chain to sustain the fighting power of UK Armed Forces worldwide; the British Forces Post Office (BFPO), which provides postal and courier Services to the Armed Forces, the MOD and other Government Departments; and the Disposal Services Authority, which has sole responsibility for the sale and disposal of all MOD surplus assets and equipment at the end of its service life.
Director Materiel Strategy leads the programme to improve the way in which Defence Equipment & Support does business.
The Materiel Strategy Head is responsible for engagement, the DE&S Baseline and International
Chief of Materiel Land assures the coherent supply and support of all Land equipments, systems and logistics to support current and future operations.

The Chief of Materiel Fleet) is responsible for the availability of Royal Navy ships and submarines, now and in the future. In addition, he oversees the effective, safe and efficient operation of the Naval Bases and leads the Maritime Change Programme.

The Air Support Operating Centre is responsible for acquisition and support for all current and future aircraft other than fast jets, including air transport, air to air refuelling, air intelligence and surveillance assets, and related training and airfield support equipment.

The MOD Commercial function is led by the Director Commercial who provides strategic leadership across the full range of MOD acquisition, procurement and commercial activities, and is responsible to CDM for all aspects of the Department's commercial performance.
The Weapons Operating Centre is responsible for all weapons and munitions programmes in DE&S.
Eliminated

Responsible for delivering future submarine concepts, design and build arrangements for the Successor SSBN and follow on SSN; including the associated infrastructure arrangements and supporting US Common Missile Compartment and technology programmes.

The Safety and Environmental Protection Group helps DE&S workplaces, services and products minimise unintentional harm to people and the environment.  It provides policy, systems, advice, guidance, training, performance information, audit and assurance.  It only does this when such support is more cost effective as a DE&S central provision than it would be if distributed within the business.

Armoured Vehicle Programmes is responsible for the development, production and in-service support of the Army’s armoured tracked vehicles and their sub-systems including Scout and the Warrior Capability Sustainment Programme.  Responsibilities also include the development, production and in-service support of Land Forces indirect fire systems, including guns, rockets, C4I, radars and joint fires integration equipment.

The Chief of Materiel Air)'s role is to provide the most senior single focal point of contact within DE&S for the Royal Air Force, to provide an operational focus within DE&S and to assure the Chief of Defence Materiel, sponsors and users that the DE&S contribution to current and future operations is coherent and effective.

Head of Commercial Combat Air is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to D Combat Air and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.
Head of Export Projects
column19: DECS staff - reported on HOCS return

column6: Head of Commercial Weapons is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to D Weapons and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.

Head of Commercial Helicopters is responsible for providing commercial advice and assurance to D Helicopters and commercial functional line management to all commercial staff within the Operating Centre.

Responsible for co-ordinating the availability of the engineering resources (standards, people and training) needed to meet the current and future requirements of the Submarine Programme.  Includes oversight of the Combat Systems Group.
Eliminated

Director Exports and Commercial Strategy is responsible for external industry-facing commercial activities which require a deep, long term understanding of the industrial base and wider MOD commercial assurance and governance tasks in support of the Investment Approvals Committee.
column19: DECS staff - reported on HOCS return

column6: Human Resources Change Advisor

The Head of Materiel Strategy DE&S+ is seeking to develop and agree a proposed on-vote solution that will transform the performance of DE&S and to ensure that DE&S could be transitioned to this model if it were chosen

The Systems Engineering & Integration Group is responsible for leading on implementing systems and software engineering across Defence. It is the MOD custodian for the 'System of Systems Approach' initiative, and undertakes the role of Chief System Architect to support Network Enabled Capability and wider defence interoperability.

The Logistics Network Enabled Capability programme exists to transform the current complex web of logistic processes and systems into a streamlined, optimised, agile and effective 'end to end' logistics support chain, fully integrated with the front line industry.

The Head of Team Complex Weapons oversees all air defence capability project teams and surface attack project teams within the Team Complex Weapons initiative, plus a number of maritime radar projects.
Submarine Support Head
Responsible for the development of Logistic Commodity Services

Soldier Systems Programmes equips and supports front line soldiers across Defence with the equipment they need to engage in dismounted close combat.  This includes small arms up to light mortars; surveillance and target acquisition equipment including night vision devices; body armour, helmets, load carrying equipment and ancilaries.  The ICG also sustains batteries across Defence, as well as hand held photographic equipment.

The Technology Delivery team is responsible for leading technology and capability investigations and demonstration programmes to expedite the exploitation of technologies into operational capability. It is the primary interface within DE&S with the Defence Science and Technology Laboratory.

The Management Accounting team provides management accounting information to MOD, the DE&S Board and Operating Centres.  Responsible for providing advice on in year management of the operating budget and the financial management of the additional funds for operations.

The Head Oil and Pipelines Agency Liaison represents the Director Commercial in his role as Departmental Sponsor of the Oil and Pipeline Agency, the only public corporation 'owned' by MOD, and the Government Pipeline and Storage System (GPSS).  GPSS stores and supplies aviation fuel to airfields throughout the UK for military and civil use.

The MOD Commercial Chief of Staff ensures commercial practitioners across Defence have the guidance, tools and advice that they need to carry out their work effectively, efficiently and in accordance with best practice.
The ISTAR programme delivery group 3 is responsible for Air Command and Control systems, including Air Defence systems.

Responsible for assisting Chief Strategic Systems Executive in his role in providing assurance to the First Sea Lord for the delivery of Continuous At Sea Deterrence.  Also responsible for the Submarine Training and Education Programme.

Responsible for the provision of commodities (spares not procured by the relevant platform team) for all aircraft, including helicopters; the procurement and support of airfield ground vehicles and equipment; and for the procurement and support of aircraft defensive and targeting aids. Also responsible for the delivery and support of flight simulators and synthetic trainers for the majority of air platforms (including helicopters).
The Chief Information Officer team is responsible for the information governance and information management processes within DE&S.
The Helicopters delivery team 3 is responsible for the continuing support and upgrading of the Apache and Chinook helicopters, as well as for all helicopter engines.

Head of the Submarine Enterprise Performance Programme, a joint MOD/Industry business transformation initiative, the purpose of which is to enable the three key submarine suppliers within the submarine enterprise to work together collaboratively with the MOD to transform the way the enterprise is delivered and managed.

Responsible for the delivery and support of surface ship combat systems and provision and support of equipment fitted to surface ships and submarines. Naval Design Partnership lead. Provision of Combat Systems subject matter expertise and processes

The UK supports the Saudi Arabian National Guard (SANG) by providing advice and assistance in the procurement, operation and maintenance of SANG communications and computer systems.  These projects are managed by the MOD, specifically by the DE&S (Director ISS) SANGCOM team, which is based mainly in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia

Professional head of Finance within the Information Systems and Services Operating Centre, responsible for financial planning, in year management, financial accounting and financial assurance and approvals
Professional head of finance within the Submarine Operating Centre, responsible for financial planning, in year management, financial accounting and financial assurance and approvals
Professional head of finance within the Combat Air Operating Centre, responsible for financial planning, in year management, financial accounting and financial assurance and approvals
DECS UAE Support International Commercial
column19: DECS staff - reported on HOCS return

column6: Director Exports and Commercial Strategy Head is responsible for external industry-facing commercial activities which require a deep, long term understanding of the industrial base and wider MOD commercial assurance and governance tasks in support of the Inves
column19: DECS staff - reported on HOCS return

column6: Responsible for the Government Owned Contractor Operated (GOCO) Materiel Strategy workstream which is working to develop and agree with a commercial partner a proposed Value for Money GOCO solution to operate and transform the performance of DE&S.
The role of the Director of Logistics Commodities and Services (LCS) is to supply logistic commodities and services in order to meet prescribed Defence capabilities in the most cost effective manner.
Logistic Commodities & Services Change Management Head
Finance Head for Chief of Materiel Land, Joint Support Chain and Logistic Commodities & Services
DES Head of Commercial Without Portfolio 1. Roving mandate for MOD Director Commercial to provide senior flexible resourcing to MOD-wide delivery of commercial solutions for defence objectives.
DES Head of Commercial Without Portfolio 2. Roving mandate for MOD Director Commercial to provide senior flexible resourcing to MOD-wide delivery of commercial solutions for defence objectives.
Director of DE&S Commercial Operations.

The Customer Support Team (Fleet) team is responsible for providing a 24/7 focal point for Defect Management and Crisis Response in support of Navy Command, providing business support to COM Fleet and developing and delivering the Navy Command Joint Business Agreement along with the associated monitoring and reporting of Maritime Performance and Risk.
The Chief Finance Officer for the Air domain provides senior financial support to the Chief of Materiel (AIR) and acts as a financial focal point within DE&S for the Air domain
The Chief Finance Officer for the Land domain provides senior financial support for the Chief of Materiel (Land) and acts as a financial focal point within DE&S for the Land domain
The Chief Finance Officer for the Fleet domain provides senior financial support to the Chief of Materiel (Fleet) and acts as a financial focal point within DE&S for the Fleet domain

The Chief Finance Officer for the Joint Enablers domain provides senior financial support for the Chief of Materiel (JE) and acts as a financial focal point within DE&S for Joint Enablers including Hels, ISTAR and ISS
DE&S Head of recruitment
